page.title: 16HISTORIC BUILDINGS-Churches
page.content: {ROXBY CHURCH_}Dedicated to St.Mary is a stone building of 14C architecture. It has a low unbuttressed western tower containing 3 bells. The south transept contains an ancient effigy which appears to have been erected over the remains of some religious person. The register dates from 1694. Recently (1984-85) restoration has been carried out by the "Manpower Services". {APPLEBY CHURCH_}The church consists of a broad low chancel. There is a spacious vestry on the north side. The chancel opens through a broad 14C arch into a nave with three bay north and south arcades with octagonal and quatrefoil piers with nailhead ornament in the capitals and lovely proportioned double arches. There is a 19C south porch and a broad western tower built in four stages.
